Stephen Bethell is the creative director of Beyond Retro, a fashion retailer known for sourcing and selling on-trend vintage clothes through it London, Brighton and Sweden based stores. Since 2011, it has also re-manufactured out of date clothes for its own label.

â€¨The garment business represents seven percent of the waste stream. The circular economy is about figuring out how we can take things out and put them back in. Thatâ€™s what weâ€™re talking about â€“ getting things from cradle to cradle, not cradle to grave,

Itâ€™s important that we all participate in a new way of looking at clothing and take responsibility. Somehow itâ€™s got to be rotated back.

Itâ€™s a simple thing to do and itâ€™s exciting. Just 25 years ago that wouldnâ€™t have been an option. It is now.

â€¨Weâ€™re making a very relevant thing out of an old thing. Three years ago we were making 500 to 600 garments a month. Now weâ€™re making 10,000 garments a month across 50 different SKUs and not only that, our customers love it. â€¨ ###Youâ€™re demonstrating the circular economy has real value.

Weâ€™re showing we can deal with that seven percent of the waste stream. Itâ€™s not only what you do with that seven per cent â€“ do you know that every time you make a pair of jeans, to grow the cotton needed takes 1600 litres of water.

If you can re-use an old pair â€“ you can save that water and save the pesticides you put on a field to grow the cotton. It has real value.

â€¨Weâ€™re really lucky that we have a trends department that is ferocious about finding the next trend. We are lucky enough to be a fashion brand that is lucky enough to participate in a circular economy. Itâ€™s about pretty clothes that allow us to have a inner smile.

â€¨###But what about cost?

â€¨Is it cheaper than making new clothes? Absolutely not. Is it comparable? Absolutely. I believe you canâ€™t start a revolution on a dress that is Â£150. A kimono that we have re-manufactured from an Indian skirt, for example, is Â£35 â€“ If we can make the revolution accessible to the Â£35 category â€“ thatâ€™s when it can happen.

â€¨###Who is the audience for you?

â€¨It is critical we make a product that is accessible to a young audience. The 18-30 year olds and we want t make a product that is not only relevant and well made but accessible.
